editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: The Choleric Fathers. A COMIC OPERA. PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL IN COVENT-GARDEN.
LONDON: Printed for G. G. J. and J. ROBINSON, Pater-noſter-row. M.DCC.LXXXV.

div.head: THE CHOLERIC FATHERS. A COMIC OPERA.
ACT I.
div.stage: SCENE I. After the OVERTURE, the Curtain riſes and diſcovers a grand Serenade before the Houſe of Don Julio Pimiento, and under Donna Zelida's window.

sp.l: THOU reſtleſs God that lov'ſt to hold
Thy vigils where Zelida dwells,
With peaceful ſleep the fair enfold;
From ſtarts and tremors, charms and ſpells,
From goblin, guard her, elf and ſprite,
Which prying haunt defenceleſs night
With eye too free and hand too bold.
Oh happy! happy! let her dream
Of ſome moſt ſweet celeſtial theme,
While Sylphs glide ſmiling by, and ſtarry meteors gleam.
With muſic charm her raviſh'd ears,
Such and ſo heav'nly as the ſpheres
Of old to wond'ring ſages play'd:
Theſe varied joys, oh love, decree,
Worthy her and worthy thee,
To nightly ſooth th' angelic maid.

div.stage: The Muſicians retire, and Jaquelina enters from the ſtreet door.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Well this is charming! This ſerenading, and theſe raptures and love—I do believe all the young Dons in Madrid are dying for my miſtreſs—Such ſweet muſic, and every night and all night long the ſame—one goes to ••• ep ſo happy, and has ſuch delightful dreams!—

div.stage: Enter Fabio on the oppoſite ſide.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Ah, my ſweet and gentle chambermaid! Of all perſons in the world, you are the very perſon I was the moſt deſirous to ſee.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Why then, my moſt ſpruce and politic ſervingman, you have only to open your eyes—And having ſeen, pray what is the nature of your very preſſing buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: An embaſſy of high import: I am Love's plenipo. Here is a letter from my maſter to your miſtreſs: I don't know the contents; but I am ſure they muſt be delicious. Are not you of my opinion?
sp.stage: [Gives her the letter in one hand, and money in the other.]

sp.speaker: Jab.
sp.p: Hum! partly.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Oh, Don Fernando writes in a very maſterly ſtile on theſe occaſions.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Pretty well, pretty well; but do you know that I was myſelf coming in ſearch of that ſweet face of your's?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Indeed! and what ſay you to my face?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Hum! I cannot ſay much in its praiſe.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Nor much in its diſpraiſe, I flatter myſelf.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: You do indeed—but go, run away with your face as faſt you can, and tell your maſter Don Fernando to wheedle his father into a good humour, and bring him here as quick as poſſible, for that our old Don is at preſent diſpoſed to treat with him concerning this ſaid marriage of their children.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Is he?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: He is a good deal alarmed at our nightly concerts, and wiſhes to ſee Zelida ſafely married.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Good!

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Overtures have been made by Don Velaſco in behalf of his ſon Don Fabricio; but in conſideration of my miſtreſs's preference of your maſter, of his father's great wealth, and of the ſtill greater pains I have taken to perſuade him in favor of Don Fernando, why—

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: We ſhall carry the day, hey?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Perhaps—You know the grudge theſe two tetchy old fathers bear one another—they are for ever diſputing, fonder of their opinions than they are of their children, and your maſter has no occaſion to be told how neceſſary caution and expedition will be in this buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: My dear delicate little dormouſe, your voice is ſweeter than the nightingale's, and your words more reviving than cherry-brandy. This intelligence will be worth a quarter's wages to me at leaſt; but you are a divine little Angel, that's the truth.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Do you think ſo?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I'll ſwear it.—Oh, apropos, my dear Jaquelina, I had almoſt forgot to tell you how deviliſhly I am in love with you.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Are you?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Deſperately! I though to have mentioned it the laſt time I ſaw you, but ſome how or other the thing eſcaped my memory—Indeed, one has ſo many affairs on hand, one cannot think of every thing; I recollected it before I had got a dozen yards from the door, but then it was too late: ſo I tied a knot in my handkerchief, as you ſee, to remind me the next time I met you.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: That was extremely kind of you. And really, you are a—tolerably—impudent—agreeable fellow.—Pray—where did you lay in all that large aſ • ortment of aſſurance?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: By a long intercourſe with people of faſhion.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: There I believe you are miſtaken, Mr. Fabio. You footmen have not learnt your agreeable aſſurance by imitating your betters, but your betters have learnt theirs by imitating you.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Upon my honor, my dear, I believe you are right; footmen and kept-miſtreſſes lead the ton.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Fabio, I muſt be gone and deliver your letter.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: You'll remember what I have ſaid to you.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: I'll tie a knot in my handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Ay, do, do.

lg.l: I'll certainly do my endeavor,
Dear Sir,
To remember your handkerchief favor,
Dear Sir;
I ſhan't want the wit to get out of your debt
Nor can I forget
That you're moſt prodigiouſly clever,
Dear Sir.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Your ſhape, air, and gait, are ſo ſtriking.
Dear Sir;
What damſel but muſt take a liking,
Dear Sir!
Turn about, Sir; look there! how genteel, debonnaire;
Well, I vow and declare!
Oh dear, you're prodigiouſly ſtriking,
Dear Sir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Now will I go in ſearch of—who have we here?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: The ſame.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Still, one of us I ſee.—And how has fortune behaved to thee ſince I ſaw thee laſt?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: As ſhe generally behaves to men of merit—very ill.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: True—I am a living proof of her injuſtice.—Had ſhe treated me according to my deſerts—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Thou had'ſt been hang'd long ago.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: What, ſtill aiming at wit—wilt thou never learn a little common ſenſe? The way to thrive, is, not to perſuade thyſelſ, but others, that they are witty.—What haſt thou got in that brown paper parcel?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: My whole eſtate, real and perſonal.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: What, all?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: All; theſe few reals exepted [holding out his hand] with which I am going to purchaſe—

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: A good lining—

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: To a bad outſide.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: No matter for that.—He that wants me, may find me, any time theſe two hours, at the three Jolly Friars.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: What, thou art in want of a place?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Why no; don't I tell thee I have not ſpent all my money?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: It's a great pity my maſter has got Don Pimiento's conſent to marry his daughter. Thou haſt an excellent turn for intrigue, and I might have helped thee to employment.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Ay, it's a damn'd ſhame fathers ſhould be ſo reaſonable and compliant—But no matter—I deſy Fortune with all her crew of obſtinate relations, called Fates and Deſtinies—When one ſpoke of the wheel is up, another muſt be down—The road of life is very hilly—full of ups and downs.

lg.l: Of ups and downs we daily ſee
Examples moſt ſurpriſing!
The High and Low, of each degree,
Now falling are, now riſing:
Some up, ſome down, ſome in, ſome out;
Some neither one nor t'other:
Knaves, Fools, Jews, Gentiles, join the • ou •
And joſtle one another;
With my heigho!
Gee-up! gee-ho!
Higgledy piggledy!
Truth, Honour, Honeſty!
Trim tram!
Your Honeſty's ſcarce,
Honour's grown a meer farce,
And poor Truth! baw! an obſolete Whim-wham.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: By ups and downs ſome folks, they ſay,
Among grandees have got, ſir;
Altho' they were but yeſterday
The Lord knows who, or what, ſir!
Sans ſenſe, or pence, in Merit's chair
They doze and dream ſupine-o!
But how the devil they came there—
That neither you nor I know.
With my heigho! &c.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Your country maid comes up to town,
A ſimple, aukward body,
In half a year again goes down,
No peacock half ſo gaudy!
Lord, ma'am! exclaims the lawyer's wife,
With ſcandal ever ready,
You ſee the ups and downs of life
Have made our Meg a lady!
With my heigho! &c.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Virtue and Vanity lately are grown
Mere buckets in a well, ſir;
The laſt gets up, the firſt gets down,
As all the world can tell, ſir.
So many downs poor Virtue meets,
Her ups ſo very few, ſir,
Tis ſaid ſhe's naked met i'th' ſtreets,
But that is nothing new, ſir,
With my heigho! &c.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Oh! what an age of ups and downs!
Hey! ſeven's the main, my lord thrice knocks;
And lands and liberties, manors and towns
Are rattling in the dice-box!
Up fly the fools! on ruin bent,
While they are full in feather;
Get pluck'd, then rumbling down are ſent
Whoop! pell-mell! all together.
With my heigho! &c.

div.stage: Enter Fernando, and his Father Don Salvador.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Be certain, ſir, your compliance in this particular would enſure my everlaſting gratitude.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: But I tell you Don Pimiento is a paſſionate, poſitive, captious—

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Nay, but hear me, ſir.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: A pretended Philoſopher! A head ſo full, of whims! So tenacious of his opinions—I hate to ſee any man tenacious of his opinions—No, no; I am fully convinced he is a weak, ſilly, wrong-headed old Lord, and I am certain all the arguments in the world will never perſuade me to the contrary.

div.stage: [During this ſpeech, Fabio takes Fernando up the Stage and whiſpers him.]

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: My dear father, I have juſt received a meſſage from Donna Zelida. She informs me, her father is conſenting to our union, and wiſhes to ſee both you and me. Surely, ſir, you will not refuſe—

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Don Pimiento wiſhes to ſee me, you ſay?

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Well; well; that being the caſe, I can have no objection to the daughter.

div.stage: [Exeunt into the houſe of Don Julio Pimiento.
SCENE changes to the muſeum of Don Julio Pimiento.
Zelida in a morning dreſs, and Jaquelina meeting.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: Return'd ſo ſoon, Jaquelina!

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: I met Don Fernando's man, Fabio, at the door, madam, he gave me this.

div.stage: [Delivering a letter, which Zelida opens and haſtily reads.]

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: Um—um—Well!—Um—um—um—um—very well!—But did you deliver my meſſage?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Oh, yes, madam, and you need not doubt but Don Fernando will ſoon be here.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: I need not queſtion his love and diligence. I am certain of his affection and ſincerity; or, whatever it might coſt me, I would not indulge the ſweet ſenſations, the raptures I feel at his remembrance.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Why, to be ſure, madam, love—love is a moſt delicious thing—And tho' theſe men fellows are ſometimes in their airs, and are proud and croſs, and unconſtant; yet they are ſometimes ſo loving, and ſo ſweet, and ſo fond, that one cannot help liking them with all their faults.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: This kind compliance of my father, to our union, will make me love him, if poſſible, better than ever.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: But why, madam, ſorry or pleas'd, vex'd of glad, do you always ſigh?

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: A ſigh, Jaquelina, is the conſtant and firſt effuſion of a feeling heart.

lg.l: When adverſe to love we ſtern deſtiny find,
And our pangs have no hope of relief,
Deſpair haunts each thought, languor ſeizes the mind,
And we ſigh with th' exceſs of our grief.
Or when, by kind fortune, revers'd is our lot,
And ſorrows no longer annoy,
Again the tear flows when the terror's forgot,
And we ſigh with th' exceſs of our joy.

div.stage: Enter Don Julio Pimiento and Fernando.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Your conſent, ſir, makes me the happieſt of men, and my heart aſſures me I ſhall become the moſt affectionate, the moſt conſtant, the tendereſt of huſbands.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: I hope ſo; Zelida deſerves the moſt affectionate and tendereſt of huſbands.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Deſerves! Oh, yes, ſir, ſhe deſerves more than the world has to give.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Tho' I partly approve your tranſports, young gentleman, you muſt moderate your ecſtacies. Let' philoſophy teach you to govern your paſſions.—I had once as much fire and rhodornontade as you, or any hotbrain'd Don in Spain. I was obliged to ſteal my wife, my Zelida's mother. I tried every kind of ſtratagem to get at her, but finding none of them were ſucceſsful, I ſet fire to the houſe, and carried my miſtreſs off thro' the midſt of the flames.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Ay, ſir, that was a lover's philoſophy.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: But go and pay your miſtreſs a morning viſit: you have no objection, I ſuppoſe. Your father and I will ſettle preliminaries.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: I am ſure, ſir, they will be to our ſatisfaction. (With heſitation.) But, excuſe a lover's fear—Let me beg, let me conjure you, ſir, to avoid every tendency to contradiction.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Ay, ay: make yourſelf perfectly eaſy; do not fear my diſcretion.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: My father, ſir, has his oddities—apt to laugh, yet every body allows him to poſſeſs noble ſentiments, and a generous heart—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: I am as willing as any man to do juſtice to the good qualities of others—Don Salvador is a gentleman and a Spaniard.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Somewhat too paſſionate, I confeſs—And then—ſir—your temper being—a little—haſty.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Haſty! I haſty!

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: That is—ſir—having—a little—generous warmth in your temper.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Warmth, young gentleman! What do you mean by warmth? No man has more philoſophy—No man can be more cool, more candid, more open to conviction.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: I own it, ſir.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Yes; but he is damn'd loth to own it tho'.—As for your father, his poſitive obſtinacy is become proverbial.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: I allow, ſir, he has a predilection for his own opinions. Let me therefore once more-intreat—

sp.speaker: D. Pim.
sp.p: 'Pſhaw! Don't I tell you, I am prepared to overlook his improprieties—Theſe modeſt hints, this advice, ſo adroitly inſinuated, is all ſuperfluous to me, and ſhould have been beſtowed at home, upon your father.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Well, ſir, I have your promiſe; on that I will depend.

lg.l: Around the ſpacious landſcape rove,
The Naiad's haunt, the Triton's bed;
Search ev'ry grot and ev'ry grove,
Where art and nature beauties ſhed.
Whate'er is rich, whate'er is rare,
Whate'er is worthieſt to be known,
Collect from ſea, from earth, and air,
From foſſil, plant, or precious ſtone.
While wonders then with wonders vie,
And latent miracles diſpenſe;
While this attracts the raptur'd eye,
And that allures the raviſh'd ſenſe:
Attentive, while the buſy ſage,
Delighted, marks the boundleſs ſtore,
Exulting, ſwells the learn'd page
With ſecrets, unobſerv'd before.
Oh come, in all thy native grace,
Zelida, come, and bleſs the view;
And ev'ry former wondrous trace
Shall vaniſh, like the morning dew.

sp.p: This is likely to be an important day. The marriage of my daughter, and the termination of my lawſuit with the houſe of Cordova!—If juſtice takes place, I cannot loſe it—And yet I have my fears—The Count has great power at court—Yet, where right is ſo evident, they will not dare do wrong.

div.stage: [Goes and ſ • ats himſelf at his library table, on which are various papers, mathematical inſtruments, crucibles, phials, &c.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Good morning, Don Pimiento.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Good morning, good morning, Don Salvador. I have lately made ſome very curious experiments, by which I find the ponderoſity of light, or, to ſpeak more philoſophically, the levity of light is extreme! All Spain by no means contains a pound.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: What do you laugh at, Don Salvador? I ſay the experiment is a very curious experiment.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Who doubts it? Ha, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Then what do you laugh at, Don Salvador?

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Laugh at? To think what a deviliſh dear commodity light is in England!—Well, here you are, like Noah in the ark, ſurrounded by all your birds, beaſts, infects, and reptiles—Ha, ha, ha! Philoſophy muſt be a plaguy expenſive plaything.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Plaything, ſir! Plaything, Don Salvador!—Let me adviſe you as a friend, Don Salvador, whenever you ſpeak of philoſophy, to do it with more reſpect, leſt you ſhould incur reproof from the learned and the wiſe—Philoſophy, Don Salvador, philoſophy is a Being of a ſuperior and divine nature; whoſe head is among the ſtars, her feet in the bottomleſs deep, and whoſe eye penetrates matter, form, and infinite ſpace, even to darkneſs and nonentity.—
sp.stage: [As the Scene advances, the laugh of Don Salvador becomes and increaſes into a laugh of vexation reſtrained.]

p.hi: Ha, ha, ha! I always told you it was ſomething monſtrous.—A divine nature! Philoſophy, Sir, is a diſſector of grubs, a painter of ſhadows—ſhe was born in amazement with her mouth open, has fed upon maggots, and peers, and pores, till ſhe fancies ſhe finds miracles ſtuff'd in the cavity of a mite's cranium, or hid in the hair of a flea's foot.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Permit me to tell you, Don Salvador, philoſophy is a thing totally beyond your comprehenſion.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Ha, ha ha!—ha, ha! yes, and yours too.—Our preſent buſineſs, Don Pimiento, is the concluſion of our children's marriage. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: It is ſo, it is ſo—and, as I have promiſed your ſon Don Fernando to be cautious, I ſhall take care to avoid all altercation.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Which promiſe, if kept, will redound very much to the honor of your underſtanding, Don Julio Pimiento. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Do you mean to inſinuate any thing to t •• diſcredit of my underſtanding, Don Salvador?

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I inſinuate nothing, Don Pimiento.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Or, that I am not circumſpect in my conduct?

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Sir, I affirm no man is leſs captious.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: You are a very worthy gentleman, Don Pimiento, but very choleric. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Choleric! I choleric!

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Were you as diſpaſſionate, as ready to liſten to reaſon as I am—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: You!—diſpaſſionate!

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Tow dipp'd in tar, will not catch fire ſo ſuddenly, or blaze out ſo furiouſly.—Oil, brandy, and Phlogiſton are not ſo inflammable.—

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—ha, ha!—You are deſcribing yourſelf, Don Pimiento, not me.—My temper, like a deep ſtream, flows on ſmooth and unruffled.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Smooth! You, Don Salvador! Flow!—Pardon me, but yours is an electic fluid, all flame!—However, be under no conſtraint; emit your ſparks; diſcharge yourſelf; I am a philoſopher, and do not fear a ſhock.—Be you as captious as you pleaſe; I ſhall be cool! cautiouſly cook.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I perceive, Don Pimiento, how remarkably you are diſpoſed to coolneſs and caution.

p.hi: What do you mean by that, Don Salvador? Am I not cool? Am I not cautious? Is it poſ • ible for any man to be more ſo?
Ha, ha, ha, ha! Well, well; where are our children?
Am I not cool, Don Salvador?
Exceedingly; as cool as you were the other day, when I laughed becauſe you aſſerted heat was nothing.
Sir, you may laugh again if you pleaſe, and I will aſſert again, and will aſſert in the face of the whole world, that heat is not a thing, but a quality.
Ha, ha, ha, ha! And ſo you ſtill perſiſt in affirming, that the blaze of a faggot, or the light of a candle, is nothing?
Sir, I affirm no ſuch thing.
And that were I to burn my finger, or ſcald my leg, I ſhould feel no pain?
I ſay, ſir, pain is a ſenſation, produced by the reaction—
And if my houſe was burnt to the ground, you would pretend it was ſtill ſtanding.
Sir, the reaction—
Or that the fiery lava of Mount Veſuvius, while it ſweeps away fields, flocks, men, and cities, is totally innocent, has nothing pernicious in its effects.
Sir, the reaction— (very loud, and very angry) Sir, I ſay no ſuch thing.
Then what do you ſay, ſir?

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Sir, you won't hear what I ſay, ſir, you can't underſtand what I ſay, ſir.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: That is your fault, ſir, for not ſpeaking intelligibly.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Do you mean to call me a fool, ſir?

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Sir, I have too much reſpect to good manners to follow your example.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Do you mean to ſay, ſir, I don't know good manners?

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: I mean to ſay, ſir, you don't practice 'em.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Sir, your ſon ſhall have no daughter of mine.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Sir, both you and your daughter would be too much honor'd in the alliance.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Too much honor'd! Jaquelina! Diego! Who waits there?—Zelida!—Somebody call my daughter.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: My dear father, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Come here, child, come away from that—

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: What, ſir?

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: My dear father, what is the occaſion of all this warmth?

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: I would ſooner marry my daughter to a deſcendant of the Cyclops, or the great grandſon of Cacus, than to the offspring of ſuch a paſſionate, perverſe,—Bu • I deſpiſe—

p.hi: My dear ſir, pray for Heav'n's ſake forbear.
What can have occaſioned—
Here has he been aſſerting again that fire won't burn, that water can't quench it, that Mahomet's black ram was an Alderney cow, and that the man in the moon wears a Harlequin's jacket.
Sir, I aſſerted no ſuch things; I deſpiſe both buffoonery and buffoons.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Deſpiſe! Do you deſpiſe me, ſir?

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.stage: (Getting between them and forcing him off)
sp.p: Pray ſir, conſder, ſir.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Sir, I deſpiſe ignorance.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake, ſir—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Sir, you are,—
sp.stage: (Zelida puts her hand over her father's mouth.)

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Sir, no man ſhall dare deſpiſe—

sp.speaker: Don. Fer.
sp.stage: (Raiſing his voice to overpower his father's, • nd forcing him out.)
sp.p: Be pacified, dear fir.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: I'll ſuffer no blockhead—

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake, dear, dear ſir, be • ool.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Cool—I am here with the determination •• be cool—I have given my promiſe to be cool; never •• my life was more circumſpect! never! never!

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: Let me beg you, ſir, to walk this way.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p:
An obſtinate, hot—I'll ſend to Don Ve
•• ſco, inſtantly! inſtantly!

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: Pray, ſir—

stage.hi: (Partly coaxes and partly drags • im off.)

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p:
So, there's an end of that buſineſs, and the lo
•• rs may get at each other if they can.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: Ah, Jaquelina!

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Ah, madam! I told you how it would be.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: My father is going to ſend for Don Velaſco; if he comes, I am ruined. Don Pimiento will pledge his word, and no power on earth then will be able to ſhake him.—Run, fly, Jaquelina, intercept the meſſage, invent ſome means—

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Ah, it's too late, madam, here is Don Velaſco himſelf.

sp.speaker: D. Vel.
sp.p: Good morning, Donna Zelida. Is Don Pimiento within?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: No, ſir; he is juſt gone out. (Turning round) Ah!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Don Velaſco, I am happy to ſee you! You are the very perſon I was going to ſend to. Zelida, go to your own chamber, and don't ſtir from thence, nor ſee any perſon whatſoever without my knowledge. (Exit Zelida.) Do you follow your miſtreſs, and ſee that I'm obeyed.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: The Devil take philoſophy, I ſay.

sp.speaker: D. Vel.
sp.p: You ſeem a little diſturbed, Don Pimiento.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: I ſhould have been, Don Velaſco, if I had not more than a common command over my paſſions.—I have been aſſaulted by an Ignoramus, inſulted by a ſneering Idiot, and I am very happy you are come.

sp.speaker: D. Vel.
sp.p: Well, Don Pimiento, which way can I—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: I believe, Don Velaſco, you recollect you did me the honor to hint that an alliance between our ſamilies would not be diſagreeable to you.

sp.speaker: D. Vel.
sp.p: It is what I very ardently deſire, Don Pimiento.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: I am happy to hear it.

sp.speaker: D. Vel.
sp.p: Your daughter is a young lady of ſuch winning manners, of ſo mild, ſo amiable, ſo ſweet a diſpoſition, that I am fully perſuaded, could my ſon, Don Fabricio, obtain the honor of her hand, it muſt make him • he happieſt of men; which is a thing, as you may ſuppoſe, I am moſt anxious to ſee accompliſh'd.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p:
Do me the honor to walk into my cabinet. Don Velaſco, we'll conclude the buſineſss in
• tantly.—I give you my word of honor, Don Velaſco, your ſon Fabricio ſhall have her.

div.stage: SCENE changes to the ſtreet again.

lg.l: He that has not a penny in pocket, or purſe,
Is ſure in a happy condition,
For bankrupts and bailiffs he cares not a curſe,

div.p: I'll keep no more company with ſkinkers.

lg.l: He hickups up ſorrow,
And laughs at to-morrow.

div.p: Knaves that pocket their pence, and talk mor-orality—Fellows that never could diſcover a pimple on their noſe.—Raſcals that will ſneak out of the world without ever beholding two o'clock in the morning.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Now muſt I go ſeck that rogue Pedro: he may become a precious implement in the preſent reverſe of our affairs—Ah! who's that? Pedro?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: The pennyleſſ.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: You are happy, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I ſay you cannot ſee: I am only half happy—T'other cup, and then—

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Another—If you have any charity, lend me a ducat.

p.hi: Not a real.
Then go and hang yourſelf—If you'll give me a bottle you are a prince, if not, you are a vile compound.
A compound?
Ay, of water, abominable water and clay.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Hark thee, Pedro, I have no time to loſe: Don Pimiento reſuſes his daughter to my maſter, and we are come to a determination to carry her off, either by artifice, or force of arms, in which thy aſſiſtance may be of ſervice.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Say no more—I'm for you— [points to his forehead] I have it—ripe—full of expedient—liquor enlightens my underſtanding, and generates ſtratagem and deep reflection—Give me but another bottle, and I'll find thee out the longitude.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Not a drop

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Well, where is this new maſter of mine? or, rather, this new landlord?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Thy landlord?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Yes; my maſter's Palace is my Inn: the only difference is, that, inſtead of his bringing me in a bill, I make him provide for me firſt, and pay afterwards for the trouble I take to eat and drink his dainties—Nature, certainly, intended me for a ſtateſman, but Fate took pity on me, and ordained that, inſtead of catering for others, others ſhould cater for me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Prithee, Pedro, what liquor in the world doſt thou love beſt?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: What a ſhallow numſkull of a queſtion is that!—I love'em all beſt—

lg.l: Your Mountain, Sack, your Frontiniac,
Tokay, and twenty more, ſir,
Your Sherry, and Perry, that make men merry,
Are Deities I adore, ſir!
Your potent Port
Muſt praiſe extort,
When from his palace forth he comes!
And glucks and gurgles! fumes and foams!
The Briton, ſir, John Barly-corn,
Stands highly in my favour;
His mantling head doth well adorn
His valor, and his flavor!
Nay Cyder-an,
Is a mighty man!
When from his palace forth he comes!
And glucks and gurgles! fumes and foams!
Old Rum, Arrack, and Coniac,
Are known for men of might, ſir!
Nor ſhall Sir Flaſket Florence lack
A place among my Knights, ſir!
Don Calcavella
Is a noble fellow
When from his palace forth he comes!
And glucks and gurgles! fumes and foams!
Madeira! Monarch! him I ſing!
And old Hock! lo! another!
Champaign is my moſt Chriſtian King!
And Burgundy's his brother!
Brave Bourdeaux! too,
Shall have his due!
When from his palace forth he comes!
And glucks and gurgles! fumes and foams!
If, ſingly, thus, each Champion may
So many laurels gather,
Gods! what a glorious Congreſs they,
When all are met together!
When, high in ſtate
Each Potentate
Forth from his ſpacious palace comes!
And glncks and gurgles! fumes and foams!

div.stage: SCENE changes to the houſe of Iſabel.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Is there no meſſage, no note from Don Fabricio?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: No, madam.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: It's very ſtrange—a mighty attentive lover!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: You know, madam, he was not to be here yet this half hour.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: What tell ye me of half hours?—But I won't teize myſelf about him—I don't care if he never comes—Who's that?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: What, madam?

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Did not ſomebody knock?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I heard nobody, madam.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: You are very ſparing of your labour—go and ſee.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.stage: (Aſide, and putting the things to rights on a table)
sp.p: I know ſhe'll bid him begone the moment he is here; her vanity is never ſatisſied, with him, or without him.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Why don't you go?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why Lord, madam, I am ſure there is nobody.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: What an odious colour'd ribband this is! (Unpins her breaſt-knot, and throws it on the table.) What a horrid dull morning!—No—he does not intend to come; or, if he does, he will expect that, becauſe one feels a partiality in his favor, one ſhould immediately tell him ſo!—In direct terms!—No, indeed!

div.head: SONG.
div.l: Wherefore tell me, ſilly lover,
I coquettiſh am, or vain?
In my looks you might diſcover
What my lips muſt not explain.
He who, when a maid denies,
Believes her words, and not her eyes,
Shall live the bye-word of the plain,
And envy ſome more happy ſwain.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Go bid the footman order my carriage—No, come back, give me my veil, I'll take a walk.
sp.stage: [Laura reaches the veil, and ſees the breaſt-knot.]

p.hi: Lord, madam, why have you taken this off? This breaſt-knot is the very colour I heard Don Fabricio praiſe ſo much yeſterday.
I am glad you have told me; I'll never wear it any more—Where is my veil?
Here, madam.
And why don't you give me the breaſt-knot?
Did not you ſay, madam?—
I never ſaw ſo ſtupid a creature! (Laura gives her the breaſt-knot, and offers to throw the veil over her miſtreſs.) What is the girl about?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Lord, madam, I declare there is no ſuch thing as pleaſing you unce you have been in love. I never knew a perſon ſo altered in my life; you are neither • atiſfied with your lover, nor yourſelf, nor your ſervants, nor any one thing about you. I am ſure, ma'am, for all I am croſs'd in love, if the defect of it was not very different upon me, we ſhould ſoon part; but it makes me all patience, meekneſs, and good nature.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Thee! Why, art thou in love?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why ſhould I not, madam? Do you think I have not a heart in my boſom as well as your ladyſhip?—I am ſure many a ſigh has my fond paſſion coſt me.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Sigh! and fond paſſion!—I ſhall deteſt the words as long as I live.

p.hi: Humph! Sugar's ſugar, tho' a body be a ſervant—And a handſome young fellow's company and kiſſes are as ſweet to us as to our betters.

lg.l: My Sancho was the deareſt youth!
My joy, my only treaſure!
Love's bleſſings dwelt around his mouth!
His eyes ſpoke peace and pleaſure!
Tho' ſuns ſhould ſcorch, or froſts ſhould bite,
Did deareſt Sancho chear me,
I'd ſing by day and watch by night,
Rejoic'd that he were near me!
For Sancho, &c.
So ſweetly on his pipe he'd play!
Oh! how I lov'd to hear him!
As jocund he, as blith as May!
'Twas heav'nly to be near him!
Oh! Sancho, &c.

div.stage: [While the Song is ſinging, Iſabel retires into an inner apartment.]

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Oh, here comes her lover; now ſhe may vent her croſs, cankerbitten humours upon him.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: How the girl ſtands! Why don't you fly to the door?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Lord, madam, the footmen have nothing elſe to do.
sp.stage: [Iſabel goes to the glaſs, looks at herſelf, and adjuſts her breaſt-knot.]

div.stage: Enter Don Fabricio. [Runs up eagerly to Iſabel.]

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: My Iſabel! My life!

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Where have you been? Why did you not come ſooner? Or, why did you come at all?

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Did you wiſh me here ſooner?

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Me wiſh you here!—Lord, let go my hand, and don't teize me.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: How can you, Iſabel, be ſo perverſe?

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Perverſe! Upon my word!—You have a very happy choice of expreſſions.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: You know my affection, Iſabel; you are ſenſible of my paſſion.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Indeed I am ſenſible of no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: I declare, Iſabel, there is no ſupporting your injuſtice.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: My injuſtice indeed! I find, ſir, you are come, as uſual, only to wrangle with me; but, I aſſure you, it would be much more prudent to ſtay at home, when you find yourſelf in theſe tempers.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: To wrangle, Iſabel? Is this to wrangle? No; I came to adore, to die for you, if it would give you pleaſure. Tell me but which way I might contribute to your happineſs, and you ſhall ſee how I will fly to execute your will.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: I beg you will riſe; you can't any way contribute to my happineſs.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.stage: (evidently very much vexed, and endeavoring to recover himſelf)
sp.p: This is hardly to be borne! Nothing, Iſabel, but love like mine, could ſupport your treatment.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Treatment! Pray which way have I treated you ill? And if I do, why do you come to me again? Who deſires your company? Have not I told you a thouſand times, I never wiſhed to ſee you more?

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Yes, cruel, unjuſt, ungrateful woman, you have; but, take care; perhaps you may tell me ſo once too often.

p.hi: So, ſo; threats too! A very pretty obedient lover, to be ſure, you are; and I am a very unjuſt, hard-hearted, lady!
Is it in the power of man to bear your caprices?
My caprices!—Inſolent!
How have I deſerv'd—
Well, well; lord I tell you, again, I wiſh you would not bring your ill humors here.
My ill humors! Did I not come with ſmiles in my face, and joy in my heart? hoping, for once, to have met a ſweet return of thoſe gentle tranſports, which I felt glowing ſo ardently in my own boſom?

Indeed, Don Fabricio, I muſt once more repeat to you, that if you can come here for no other purpoſe but to find fault with me; to tell me I am unjuſt, ungrateful, capricious, and heap every other kind of aſperſion upon me, you can invent; I muſt beg, and inſiſt, you will never come here any more.

Very well, Iſabel, very well, ſince I am ſo totally diſagreeable to you, and ſince your commands are ſo very abſolute, you will find I am not ſo pitifully abject as to be thus repeatedly and everlaſtingly ſcorn'd and repuls'd.—Yes, I will obey theſe your poſitive, your haughty commands, and perhaps with more fortitude than you expect, perhaps more than you wiſh.
Wiſh! Indeed! I wiſh!

Yes, more than you wiſh; you cannot ſo diſguiſe your wiſhes, but they will appear in ſpite of that caprice by which they are clouded; nay, had I not been well perſuaded you had a partiality, and a ſtrong one, in my favor, I ſhould not ſo long have endured the injuſtice of your behaviour; but, while I ſaw it, and felt my own paſſion as pure, and, at leaſt, as ardent, as yours, I hoped, vainly, I find, it might be poſſible to conquer that coquettiſh, unworthy, and diſſtisfied humor by which you are tormented.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Pray, ſir—How dare you, ſir!—Be gone, ſir! this inſtant be gone! and never preſume to obtrude yourſelf into my preſence again!

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Obtrude?—Yes, haughty lady, I will be gone, and obſerve your injunction, punctually, literally.—Good morning.—
sp.stage: [Don Fabricio, going, is met by Don Fernando.]

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Fabricio, this is fortunate! I came purpoſely, hoping to meet you. [Looking round, and obſerving the diſorder of Fabricio and Donna Iſabel, who has ſat down] But!—You!—What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: An ungrateful—proud—paſſionate— [burſts into tears] There is no ſupporting his treatment.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: They have been quarrelling—He wants to break with her, no doubt, that he may be at liberty to marry Zelida.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: I am determined I will be no longer the Dupe of her caprice.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Yes; it is evidently ſo. [to Don Fabricio with an air of chagrin.] You have heard, I preſume, Don Fabricio, of the treaty between your father and Don Pimento?

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Concerning what, Sir?

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Your marriage with Donna Zelida.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I have.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: And pray give me leave to aſk you, Don Fabricio, what you think of that treaty?

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: I think it would be a very wiſe treaty for me, Sir.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: And—and—and you conſequently think, Zelida—

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: An Angel! I do upon my ſoul, Sir.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: But give me leave to obſerve t'ye, Don Fabricio, there are prior claims.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Claims that will be ins;iſted on, Sir.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: I perceive you are growing angry, Don Fernando; and as I am not very cool, at preſent, I ſhall bid you a good morning.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Before you go, Sir, I demand a categorical anſwer.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: And with that menace on your face?

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: No equivocation, Sir.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Hark ye, Don Fernando, if you ſhould meet any hot, iraſcible young gentleman of your acquaintance, who wants to be taught manners, pray inform him my name is Fabricio, and that I am to be found on the Prado at five.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Sir!— (Going to follow, but ſtops ſhort) Perhaps I am to blame—it is evident he and Iſabel have quarrell'd—I will enquire further of her—Yet why did he avoid an explanation?—The charms of my Zelida are irreſiſtable!—She muſt, ſhe ſhall be mine: yes, I will indulge the flattering idea.

lg.l: As, lonely, thro' the mead, or grove,
Or by the limpid ſtream,
Of thee, Zelida! while I rove,
Indulging fancy's dream,
I hear thy voice, enchanting maid!
Thy beauteous form I feign,
Strange tranſports ev'ry ſenſe invade!
And thrill thro' ev'ry vein!

lg.head: II.
lg.l: If fancied Pleaſures are ſo great,
And feeble Memory may,
Thus, with her phantoms, captivate!
Theſe ecſtacies convey!
If, abſent, I, entranc'd, may feel
Senſations ſo divine!
What raptures ſhall that hour reveal
Which makes thee wholly mine!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Thou ſeeſt the effects, Fabio, of half an hour's ſleep, a wet napkin, and a razor.—Now am I as freſh as if it were midnight.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Don Fernando bade me follow him hither—Oh, here he comes.

div.stage: Re-enter Don Fernando, and Donna Iſabel.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: What you tell me gives me a thouſand fears and ſuſpicions. I was accuſing myſelf, while he, perhaps, was artfully exciting me to a quarrel that might ſerve his own purpoſes.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: It is but too probable—Fabio—Oh, this, I ſuppoſe, is Pedro?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: And your humble ſervant, ſir.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Fabio has given me a high character of thy abilities. Haſt thou conſidered—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: The affair, I believe, ſtands thus, ſir: Your fathers have quarrelled, are paſſionate and obſtinate. One of them is a pretended philoſopher, or rather a philoſophic news-monger.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: He is ſo.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Who makes a few nick-nack experiments and liſtens with avidity to the diſcoveries of others, which he publiſhes as his own, in the very teeth of the perſon from whom he received his information.

p.hi: You have a deal of obſervation, Mr. Pedro?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Obſervation is the eſſence of genius, madam, and genius is not confin'd to rank.—I muſt get introduced to Don Pimiento, as a philoſopher juſt come from Paris or Piſa, or any other place far enough off—if I could learn what is the philoſophic chit-chat, the wonder of the day—

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: What I can procure: I have a college acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: An expedient muſt next be found to wheedle, or terrify, Don Salvador into compliance.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: I can think of none.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Leave that to me, ſir.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: But Don Fabricio!

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: What of him, madam?

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Is this lady's lover, and, as we ſear, has been quarrelling with her for the purpoſe of being at liberty to marry Zelida.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Then we muſt have ſome plot for him alſo.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: But is thy brain as fertile as thou ſeem'ſt to think?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Time muſt determine, ſir.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Well, I promiſe thee that ſucceſs, in this affair, ſhall make thy fortune.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Ah! ſir,—he that has a heart as merry as mine—why his fortune's made.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Yes—but a little money—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Oh Laud!—Ay, ſir—is an excellent thing!—Money!—money is the father of mirth—and mother too egad.—He that does not want money will never want relations.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: We will not be ungrateful, Mr. Pedro.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.l: Love's pleaſures, ſurely, ſhould be great,
For, ah! too frequent is the pain.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.l: Yet ſtill, its ills to mitigate,
Our griefs find eaſe while we complain.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Lord! ma'am, Don Fabricio's gone hence in a huff!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I met him; he look'd moſt confoundedly gruff!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: He ſtar'dl

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Cock'd his hat!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Twirl'd his thumbs!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Bit his lips!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: And look'd full as glum as—as—as

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: The moon in eclipſe!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Love's pleaſures, &c.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: SCENE I. The ſtreet before Don Julio Pimiento's door, which ſhuts to.

sp.p: SO, our ſham philoſopher has got admittance.—I wiſh it were poſſible to ſee Jaquelina; but that, indeed, is not to be hop'd.—Hey! who's this? (retires a little, peeping.) By Jupiter, it is ſhe herſelf!

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: I have eſcaped for a moment, if I could but find that—

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Ah, my ſweet gilliflower!—This is lucky; we concluded you and your miſtreſs were cloſe priſoners.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: No; we are on parole, at preſent.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: And you have taken a liberty natural to your ſex, eſpecially to chambermaids, and ſtrayed beyond your limits.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: If ever we do ſtray, you men are the firſt to tempt, and the firſt to reproach us.—But come, come; tell me, what does your maſter intend to do?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Hang himſelf, if he can't marry your miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: 'Pſhaw! let him marry firſt, he may hang himſelf afterwards.—But there is no time to be loſt.—Has he any plan?—any—

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Oh yes, an excellent one!—Deſpairing of meeting you, my maſter has ſent a letter to your miſtreſs, by a philoſopher.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: A philoſopher!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: A pretended one, an arch fellow; one Pedro; but, unleſs he ſees you, he may find no means of conveying his letter.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: I muſt be gone then.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: No hurry—It may be ſome time, perhaps, beſore we meet again; and you muſt know, Jaquelina, that ever ſince I told you how prodigiouſly I was in love with you, I have thought of nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Then your memory is vaſtly improved.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I really believe, if you give me encouragement, as I have no doubt you will, I ſhall be mad enough to marry.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Don't be too certain, ſir; I aſſure you, I am very difficult to pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Are you? why pray tell me what ſort of a huſband you would wiſh?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: I would have him very patient, for I am paſſionate, and hate contradiction; very induſtrious, for I don't love work, yet ſhould chuſe to have every thing decent about me; very handſome, for I muſt inſiſt on having pretty children—

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Ah! that I am afraid won't entirely depend upon me.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Very brave, for I am apt to quarrel, and want a protector; then he ſhould have ſome money, for I love pleaſure, fine cloaths, and good living; a neat perſon, for I hate a ſloven; a genteel appearance, for I ſhould prefer a gentleman-like carriage; beſides which, he muſt have underſtanding enough to commit no follies himſelt, and to overlook all thoſe that I commit.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Well, my dear, the article of money excepted, you may find all theſe perfections united in me.—Indeed, I am perſuaded, fate deſigned us for each other. For my own part, I can ſafely ſay, I am one of the clevereſt fellows, and beſt creatures, breathing.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: You are?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I am, upon my honor.—We ſhall be vaſtly happy; as the proverb ſays: we ſhall wear too heads under one hat.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Two heads under one hat! two heads under one cap, if you pleaſe, ſir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Nay, as you pleaſe, my dear.

p.hi: And, if I do marry, I ſhall not chuſe too many children.—Not above a pigeons pair at the very moſt.
Granted.
The boy ſhall be monſtrous clever.
Be it ſo.
But the girl!—The girl ſhall be the greateſt genius, and the fineſt perſon!—That is, ſhe ſhall be the very moral of me.
To be ſure, my dear—I'll take particlar care about that.

She ſhall have a fine neck, an elegant ſhape, a moſt beautiful face, a charming leg and foot; then, as I was a ſaying, ſhe ſhall be a monſtrous great genius—She ſhall dance delightfully, ſing divinely, play on the muſic like an angel, and paint like a goddeſs, without ever being taught.
Without ever being taught!
To be ſure—Don't I tell you ſhe is to be a genius?
Very well, my dear, ſhe ſhall be juſt what you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Yes; I expect everything is to be juſt as I pleaſe.

lg.l: Cold or hungry, wet or weary,
Huſbands ever muſt be pleas'd:
Nor with ſaucy pout, or query,
Wives muſt ever once be teas'd:
Patient, humble,
Unknown to grumble,
Seldom angry, ſoon appeas'd;
Cold or hungry, wet or weary,
Huſbands ever muſt be pleas'd.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Tho' of folly they're convicted,
Yet, ſhould they the fact deny,
Wives muſt not be contradicted;
Nor once aſk for reaſons why:
Swinging, dinging,
Scolding, ſinging,
If they laugh, or if they cry,
Wives muſt not be contradicted;
Nor once aſk'd for reaſons why.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Well, Fabio, have you any intelligence? Has Pedro got admittance?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, and I have luckily met Jaquelina, who is now informed of our plan.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: That's fortunate! watch hereabouts 'till Pedro comes back, that, in caſe of any accident, you may be at hand: but keep out of ſight. (Fabio retires) If this fellow ſhould be detected, what reſource ſhall I find next?—anxious, reſtleſs, hoping, fearing, I am uneaſy and unhappy every where—Oh, Zelida!

lg.l: When gloomy thoughts my ſoul poſſeſs,
Alike in palace, plain or grove,
Fond ſighs my griefs and pangs expreſs;
And plaintive ſongs of joyleſs love.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: When doubts, impatient, rend my heart,
As rends the hawk the turtle-dove,
Indignant, from each wound I ſtart;
And ſing the wrongs of injur'd love.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: But ſhould my pangs, endur'd ſo long,
The cruel Fates to mercy move,
I'd gladly change the mournful ſong;
And ſweetly ſing the joys of love.

div.stage: SCENE, the Muſeum of Don Julio Pimiento.
Enter Don Julio Pimiento, and Pedro as a philoſopher.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Sir, I have correſpondents in all parts of the world. It is the buſineſs of my life to ſeek out men famous in philoſophy; and, being at Madrid, could not neglect the opportunity of being known to a philoſopher ſo renown'd as el nobliſſimo, y ſavantiſſimo, y eloquentiſſimo, y Venerabiliſſimo, Don Julio Pimiento de Sandovalo.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Sir, from the profound reſpect you pay to philoſophers, I can make no doubt but you are, yourſelf, a philoſopher of the firſt diſtinction.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Sir, modeſty always imprints her mark upon merit. I ſhall therefore ſay nothing of my own abilities. I ſhall only hint, ſir, that if you can find on the earth's circumference ſo deep a thinker, ſo juſt a reaſoner, ſo acute an obſerver, ſo—but, ſir,—modeſty—modeſty forbids me to finiſh my ſentence.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: And have you travelled far, ſir?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Far? From the Arctic to the Antarctic: I have viſited all countries, climates, and nations, known and unknown.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Unknown!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: U—u—un—known; yes, ſir, unknown—except to myſelf.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Sure, ſir, you—you—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I lie, he means to ſay—Sir, have you ever heard of air balloons?

p.hi: Somewhat, ſir, but very imperfectly. I—I ſhall—
Sir, I'll explain that matter t'ye more fully another time.
You ſay you have correſpondents? Can you inform me how foreign philoſophers are at preſent employed?
Exactly. In Sweden and the North, they are making experiments; in Germany, they are making ſyſtems; in France, they are making fortunes; and in England, they are making parachutes.
Parachutes? Pray, ſir, what are they?
A parachute, ſir, is a—a—mathematical inſtrument, vulgarly called an umbrella, into which if you put a cat, you may toſs her from the top of a houſe without breaking her neck.
That you might have done before, ſir—But can you toſs a dog?
No, ſir.
Or a ſheep?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Oh no, ſir, a cat is your only animal for a parachute—Pray, ſir, are you a Meſmerite?

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: A Meſmerite, ſir? what is a meſmerite?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Is it poſſible, ſir, that you ſhould never have heard of Meſmer?

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Never, ſir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Nor Deſlon?

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Nor of that ſublime—ſublimity—animal magnetiſm?

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Never, never, ſir—What is it? What is it?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Is it! Sir—It—It is—It—It—Sir—It is ſo—wonderful!—ſo—profound!—ſo—I—I can't tell you what it is.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Then it muſt be profound indeed?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Oh, ſir—It—Do you keep any females in the houſe?

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: To be ſure, ſir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I thought, ſir, as a philoſopher you might exclude them your manſion.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Why they are but troubleſome animals, I own.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Oh, here comes one. Young woman, ſtand ſtill.
sp.stage: [Strips up his ſleeve, takes a letter out of his pocket, puts himſelf in a poſition, and points to Jaquelina with his fore-finger, endeavouring at the ſame time to make her perceive the letter that he holds behind his back in his other hand.]

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: What are you about, ſir?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Going to magnetize this young woman.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Magnetize me indeed!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Yes, young woman! Walk round that way.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Do as you are bid, huſſy.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: That way, that way; a little more that way.

div.stage: [Endeavouring to make her ſee the letter.—Jaquelina at laſt perceives his intention, takes the letter, reads the direction, and throws it ſpitefully away.]

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Um—um—um—um—um—um—What mummery is this?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: It is for your miſtreſs Zelida, and ſo directed to avoid detection.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: What? What is that? What is that?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: This young woman is in ſuch robuſt good health it will require longer time to—
sp.stage: [Again putting himſelf in an attitude; Jaquelina takes, and endeavours to conceal, the letter.]

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: But what letter is that?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.stage: (Pretending to diſcover that Jaquelina has it.)
sp.p: Ha! young woman, how came you by this letter?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: You juſt now dropped it, ſir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: This letter, Don Pimiento!—Ah! if you knew the contents of this letter!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: To the moſt famous and renowned maſter of all ſciences, Dr. Don Lilibulero. Is it curious?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Sir, were you to read it, you would never recover from your ſurpriſe!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: It would give me vaſt pleaſure! Permit me to—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Pardon me, Don Pimiento, it is impoſſible.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: What, it contains philoſophic ſecrets I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Secrets! Ay, ſir, ſecrets that would make your hair ſtand on end!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: If this buſineſs ſucceeds, and it is at preſent in an excellent train, the young ſhall rejoice, and the old ſhall laugh.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Laugh!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Ay, ſir, laugh!—Nay, what is more ſtrange, ſhall be laugh'd at.—And to convince you, Don Pimiento, of the confidence I place in you, I will venture to inform you, that this whole affair is a ſcheme, to make a fool of a Philoſopher.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Ah!—I conceive—not a—a—a deep—You underſtand me—but ſome ſhallow—dabbler.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: The very man.

sp.speaker: D. Pim?.
sp.p: To convince him of his error, and at the ſame time ſurpriſe the world with a diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Sir, if you knew the letter by rote, you could not better divine its purport. Could not you let this pretty maid ſtep and put it into the poſt?

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.stage: (Going to give it her; but turns back)
sp.p: But you'll give me your word of honor, Don Pimiento, not to endeavor, directly or indirectly, to come at the contents.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Such a promiſe is needleſs, ſir, but I do give you my word of honor.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Here, young woman, take it inſtantly, and there is ten ducats for your trouble.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Ten ducats! Zounds! he is very liberal! This muſt be ſome rare ſecret indeed, that he is in poſſeſſion of!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Be very careful.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Oh, don't you doubt me.
sp.stage: (Eyes Pedro, the dreſs, the ducats, the letter, &c. All the time endeavouring to reſtrain her laughter.)

div.head: SONG.
div.l: Never fear, I'll take care of your letter,
I'm as cute as another; why not?
Jaquelina, no chambermaid better,
Has ſtudied the trim of what's what.
Tho' grave your
Behaviour,
Your letter, your outlandiſh looks, ſir,
Your ducats, which better than books are,
By half,
Your air aſtronomical,
All are ſo comical,
Excuſe me! I muſt take my ſwing!
For there's no ſuch thing
As forbearing to laugh!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: The jade! How merry the ducats have made her!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I take it for granted you have no children, Don Pimiento.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Pardon me, ſir, I have a daughter.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Indeed!—Is ſhe married?

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: No, ſir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Hum!—ſorry for it—A philoſopher ſhould live as undiſturb'd as the ſpiders in his window.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: But ſhe will be ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: The ſooner the better—Girls are ever in love, and then their wits are all ſet to work to deceive—Love letters, rope ladders, and elopements are their continual ſtudy—You are right; marry her—marry her—and to the man ſhe loves—Let her be miſerable her own way.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: But I hope to ſee her happy, for which reaſon

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Fool that I am! What have I forgot?

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: What is the matter, ſir?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: The moſt neceſſary thing in the whole proceſs!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: What ſir? What?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I beg ten million of pardons, Don Pimiento, ten million of pardons; but muſt inſtantly be gone to prepare the ſecond part to my letter. 'Tis of the utmoſt conſeqence! The affair can't wait a moment!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Sir, I would by no means intrude upon time ſo valuable; but, when more at leiſure—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Oh ſir, you will be certain to ſee me again: have not the leaſt doubt, ſir, that I can forget a Philoſopher ſo renowned as—

div.head: DUET.
div.l: El nobliſſimo! y ſavantiſſimo!
Y eloquentiſſimo! y venerabiliſſimo!
Don Julio Pimiento de Sandovalo!
To whom unpeopled lands ſhall know
How much they owe.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Moſt learned, ſcientific ſir!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Nay, I inſiſt, you ſhall not ſtir!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Permit me, ſir!—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: You muſt not ſtir!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: I beg, kind ſir—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: You ſhall not ſtir!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: If any thing new ſhould occur—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: You ſhall hear of me, ſir.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Be ſo kind as to call when you're in our vicinity.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: This vaſt honorificabilitudinity
Commands my eſteem!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Any project or ſcheme—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Sir, your's is the clover—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Oh! dear ſir!—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: The cream—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Kind ſir!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: The virginity
Of all I diſcover.
I find in myſelf an incompoſſibility—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Do not ſtir,
To expreſs my eſteem!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Learned ſir, your civility!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Your admirability!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Would I had docility—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: And I volubility—

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: To expreſs my eſteem.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Learned ſir!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Do not ſtir.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: This vaſt honoriſicabilitudinity
Commands my eſteem!

div.stage: SCENE changes to the houſe of Don Salvador.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I muſt requeſt, Mr. Fabio, you will lay aſide ſome of this familiarity, and put on a little more reſpect and reſerve. Conſider the difference between laqueys, like you, and a perſon of my character and conſequence.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I own, Pedro, thou, like many others, doſt aſſume, and very naturally too, a conſequence to which thou haſt no pretenſion. But come, my Philoſopher, tell me what ſcheme thou haſt next, in order to ſucceed with Don Salvador, as well as thou haſt done with Don Pimiento?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: There are but two keys to the human heart, Hope and Fear, and this obſervation, friend Fabio, if thou wert not naturally very ſhallow, would convince thee, I am really more of a Philoſopher than thou dream'ſt of.—Canſt thou tell me what thing in this world Don Salvador fears the moſt?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: The inquiſition.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: An attempt was once made upon him, for the ſake of his wealth, by thoſe holy fathers, which he got clear of with honor; but which gave him ſo much trouble, and terror, that ever ſince, he has held the holy office, and all its implements, in utter dread and abhorrence. The very name of an inquiſitor will make him quake like the baſs-ſtring of a harpſichord.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Then I am an inquiſitor.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Thou!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Shut thy mouth, and on with thy obſervations, if thou haſt any thing more to communicate.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: The inquiſitors being all eccleſiaſtics, Don Salvador deteſts, and never fails to take his revenge on, all orders and degrees belonging to the church, whenever he thinks he can do it with ſafety.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Enough, thou haſt uttered volumes.—Philoſophy, for the preſent, muſt, as it has often done before, give place to religion.—Wait a little, and prepare to wonder.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha! the rogue is certainly ſome runaway jeſuit.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Where is your maſter, ſirrah, Fabio?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Lord, poor young gentleman! it is impoſſible I ſhould tell, ſir: your folks croſs'd in love never know where they are themſelves, and how ſhould I?

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: What, is his paſſion very violent?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Oh, ſir, monſtrous!

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: So much the better; your very violent love never laſts long.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe he ſhould turn deſperate, ſir, and put an end to himſelf?

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Why, then, there will be an end to all his troubles. A dead man has no need of a wife, which ought to be no ſmall comfort to him.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: How can you, who are his father, talk ſo?

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Becauſe, I, who am his father, know him too well to be under any apprehenſion.

div.stage: Re-enter Pedro in a friar's habit.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: How, now! who let in this friar? What is your buſineſs, ſir?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I am come, ſon—

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: I am no ſon of your's, friend; I'm too old to be your baſtard.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Tho' not thy carnal, I am thy ghoſtly father, and with all humility—

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Prithee, friend, let us have no abuſe of terms. Not ghoſtly, but ghaſtly, thou art: carnal I believe thee to be; and as for humility, that, as well as charity, thou expecteſt from others; friars never keep any themſelves.—But what do you do here, friend? What is your buſineſs? I want no confeſſor: I have one already, and that is one too many.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I am exceedingly ſorry to find ſin ſo inverterate in a head ſo grey. I come to thee, ſon, in all meekneſs.—

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Yes, a wolf in ſheep's cloathing. Who are you?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Thou doſt interrogate with great haughtiness. I am Calificador to the holy office.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.stage: (Trembling exceedingly, and pulling off his hat.)
sp.p: Sir! an inquiſitor!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: An inquiſitor; and exceedingly grieved to find an aged perſon, whom I believed a true ſon of the church, a hardened ſinner, and a heretic.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Sir, I beg a thouſand pardons, I—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: And is it thus you treat our ſacred fraternity? Were not the church over merciful, in long forbearance, no impious reprobate would dare thus to inſult her too patient, ſuffering, ſpirit.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Sir, I do not dare, I never did dare, offend the pious, gentle, mild, lenient, fathers of the holy inquiſition. I reſpect, I revere, I adore—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: But tho' to ſuccor, and to ſave, be her delight, ſhe has an arm to puniſh.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Pray, moſt reverend father, hear me a moment.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Her mercy is great, but her wrath is dreadful!

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: I will make any atonement.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Whips, racks!—

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: A thouſand piſtoles.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Screws, pullies!—

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Two thouſand.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Gridirons!—

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Three thouſand.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Fires, flames, and faggots!

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Four thouſand.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.stage: (ſtops, and looks with great gravity over his ſhoulder.)
sp.p: Four thouſand piſtoles?

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Four thouſand, and whatever penance your pious hand ſhall pleaſe to inflict.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Four thouſand piſtoles.—Were not the church the kindeſt, beſt, of mothers, her naughty children could not ſo eaſily appeaſe her wrath; but ſhe is aged and poor; ſhe has ſuckled and ſed them, till they are become unruly, rich, and rampant; ſhe—Where are the four thouſand piſtoles?

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: I'll fetch them inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Stop—be not deceived; do not ſuppoſe, that blaſphemy, ſo heinous as you have uttered, can be ſo eaſily pardoned.—But, bring the money; and, then, if I find you an obedient ſon in matters which I will explain to you—why, perhaps.—But, bring the money.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Oh, unfortunate day! Curſt, unlucky adventure!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha! thou haſt terriſied the old gentleman half out of his wits! Thou doſt it rarely! But, hark thee, Pedro—concerning the four thouſand piſtoles?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: What of them?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: We ſhare.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Not ſo much as a marvedy.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Oh, yes, we muſt halve' em.

div.stage: Re-enter Don Salvador, with a bag, and overhears their converſation.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Tho' really thou art an unconſcionable rogue, Pedro. Four thouſand piſtoles! Why zounds! thou wilt ſet up for a German Prince with thy ſhare!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: My ſhare! I have conſcience enough to take care, Mr. Fabio, that you ſhall not touch a doit.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I'll have two thouſand; nay, if thou mak'ſt another word, I'll have three, or blow.—

div.stage: [Don Salvador comes down, and places himſelf between them, looking firſt at one, then at the other, while they alternately ſteal off as he takes his eyes from them.]

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Stop, ſtop, Mr. Inquiſitor, and take your money.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I'll call another time, Sir.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p:
A mighty fine ſcheme this! and I had like to have been moſt excellently chouſed. That raſcal Fabio in the plot too! Who can the ſcoundrel be?—Oh my poor dear four thouſand piſtoles!—But if I lay hands on him, I'll make him pay for the panic he put me into—This muſt be ſome trick of that ſilly old philoſopher Don Pimiento—Yes, he feels he is ridiculous himſelf,
and wiſhes to make others the ſame—Ha, ha, ha!—ha, ha—a fine tale he would have made on't!—He would have told it to all his birds and beaſts—ha, ha, ha,—ha, ha!—He does not perceive that his cellection of owls, jack-daws, and jays, baſiliſks, blind worms, bulls, and baboons, are a univerſal ſatire upon himſelf, nay indeed upon the world.

lg.l: Of all your poetical Tuum and Meum,
Moſt pregnant, in ſimile, is a Muſeum:
Brutes, reptiles, birds, plants are lampoons upon life;
A Huſband is Hellebore, Wormwood a Wife.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: A Vintner's a Jackall; an Author's a Grub;
Coquettes are Camelions; a Beau's a Bear's cub,
'Till barbers and taylors have lick'd him to ſhape,
And when metamorphos'd he is but an Ape.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Cuckoo-Courtiers are peck'd at, when too near the Throne,
And have mates who but ſeldom hatch eggs of their own;
Politicians, like Polypi, never can ceaſe,
For the more you divide them the more they increaſe.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Led Captains are ſnails, who, oppos'd, ſtill recede,
Shrink, pull in their horns, and beſlime where they feed;
A Poet (a modern one) drone-like, conceals,
Debaſes, and lives on the honey he ſteals.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Some call him a Spider, whoſe venom, they ſay,
Spun into non-naturals, poiſons his prey;
Man-tygers are Bailiffs, who lurk 'till they've claw'd ye,
And ſuck up your blood ere they mangle your body.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: A Lawyer a nondeſcript monſter we deem;
Shark, Whale, or Leviathan's nothing to him:
His green-bag's a belly which ſimile mocks,
For it ſwallows up houſes, fields, foreſts and flocks!

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: But he who to cite ev'ry emblem ſhould dare,
Of Reptile and Raſcal! of Bully and Bear!
While prating of Aſſes, Owls, Monkies and Goats,
Might cut his own fingers and other folks throats.

div.stage: SCENE changes to the apartment of Donna Zelida.
Enter Zelida and Jaquelina; Zelida holds two letters in her hand.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Pray, madam, conſider: do nothing haſtily.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: No, Jaquelina, there is but one way of acting; that muſt be purſued, determinedly: to consider were to be loſt.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Only read the letter once again, madam, before you fend your anſwer.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: It is needleſs; every word is imprinted in my memory. Yes, Fernando, I own thy image is engraven on my heart. To loſe thee were everlaſting wretchedneſs; but deſtiny, alas! is more powerful th •• love.

div.head: SONG.
div.l: The foreſt boughs, that oft have felt
The pruning Woodman's wound,
In vain accuſe the exe and belt
With which they're lopt and bound:
Could I the arm of Fate direct,
Thy ſorrows, Youth, ſhould ceaſe;
Thy days ſhould Love and Joy protect,
Thy years ſhould ſmile in peace.

div.stage: (After the ſong, goes to deliver the letters to Jaquelina)—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Well, Zelida!

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: Ah! (Zelida in confuſion endeavours to conceal the letters, by putting them in her work-bag. Don Pimiento gets a glance of them.)

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: You—you ſeem a little confuſed, child.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Lord, ſir, you come ſo ſuddenly into young Ladies' rooms—My—my miſtreſs was—ſhe was—was—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: She was?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. (Jaquelina ſteals round Zelida, and ſlily takes the work-bag out of her, hand. As ſhe is paſſing behind Don Pimiento to get to the door, he keeps his eye on her, and ſeizes her by the arm.)

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Lord, ſir, let me go, I want—

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Lord, ſir, let me go, I want—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Don't be in a hurry, child, I wan't too.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: What, Sir?

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: To ſee your t' other hand, child.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.stage: [Lets the work-bag drop behind her, and ſhews it him.]
sp.p: Well, there Sir, what would you ſee?

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p:
Really, my dear, you underſtand Hocus Pocus very well; but pray move a little farther that way—a little farther. [Jaquelina keeps kicking the work-bag, behind her; he holds her with one hand, and with the other takes it up, and feels the Letters] Ha, child! Yes, they are here I believe—My friend the Philoſopher was very right—Love letters here are—Rope-ladders and elopements will come next, I ſuppoſe—But we ſhall ſee— [Takes the
Letters out, reads the ſuperſcription, and ſtarts with amazement.] How! What! 'To the moſt famous, moſt renowned Maſter of all Sciences, Dr. Don Lilibulero! 'Indeed!, Deareſt Zelida'—Begins very learnedly!—, 'Tis impoſſible to expreſs the torments I this moment 'ſuffer—I have ſent you this by my Valet, diſguiſed purpoſely 'to deceive your father; hope you will lend him your 'aſſiſtance'—Ah that he need not doubt of—, Conſider, 'Zelida, my life is at ſtake! to outwit thoſe who would 'ſacrifice our happineſs to their own caprice will be meritorious: 'we cannot better fulfil our duty'—Moſt dutiful 'Sir!—, Life or death will be the conſequence of your 'anſwer, to the hoping, deſpairing, miſerable 'FERNANDO.'

And miſerable may you remain!—So Madam!—So Mr, Philoſopher! Theſe are your ſecrets—And— [to Jaquelina] you! Mrs. Ten Ducats!—But he is gone to prepare the ſecond part, I ſhall be ſure to ſee him again—So, moſt dutiful Lady! you who are a pattern of virtue, and diſcretion, and meekneſs.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: My deareſt father, hear me but for a moment.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: You can give countenance to impoſtors, and join in rendering your father ridiculous to the whole world—But this, no doubt, is your anſwer. 'To Don Fernando.'—Yes, yes;—We ſhall now ſee your dutiful ſentiments diſplayed at full length; I ſhall here find myſelf painted in moſt beautiful colours.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, my deareſt father, pardon my indiſcretion.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p:
Indiſcretion! A moſt gentle term indeed for conſpiring to diſhonour your family, to diſgrace your father, and to render him the ſubject of a footman's ballad in every twopenny taphouſe—But we ſhall ſee, we ſhall ſee. (Opens the letter and reads.), I am aſhamed of 'myſel,—Well you may, indeed!—I am aſhamed 'of myſelf when I find my conduct has been ſuch, 'Fernando, as could authorize your preſent proceedings, '—How, how!—, I muſt be the moſt undutiful, 'the worſt of children, could I, any way, wilfully 'contribute to ſee my father ſo indecenty impoſed upon,— (Looks at Zelida.) My girl! my child!—When
'authorized by my father, I did not ſcruple to confeſs 'my affection for you, nor do I, ſtill, to own that his 'conſent to our union would, perhaps, give me as much 'pleaſure as you; but, without his conſent, I never will 'be your's,—Zelida!—, I cannot pardon myſelf for 'having received your letter without his knowledge; and 'I aſſure you, no power on earth ſhall ever make me 'your's, if, after the receipt of this, you continue to 'impoſe on him by means which, tho' perhaps not ſo 'conſidered by you, are degrading and inſulting.,' [Don Pimiento weeps aloud, and lets the letter fall out of his hands.] Zelida!—You are a good girl, Zelida! A good girl!—But that damn'd raſcal, that Philoſopher, that footman, that ſcoundrel—Diego— [Don Pimiento keeps weeping in the midſt of his extreme anger.]

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: I feel, ſir, you have been very improperly treated; but let me conjure you to conſider that—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Conſider! I'll be revenged!

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: But, ſir, if you would but remember a little philoſophy—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Damn philoſophy! I'll be revenged— [Still weeping.]. Diego!—Guilermo!—

div.p: Get me a blanket, a ſtrong one, a new one, never worn.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: Have mercy, ſir, upon the poor fellow; he is but a footman. It will degrade you to—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Will it?—But, if it degrades me, it ſhall elevate him—And tho' you are a good girl, Zelida, you are a little pitiful, and therefore, that neither you nor your ten ducat waiting-woman may convey any intelligence to the raſcal, I muſt keep you under lock and key a little while.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: Let me know but what your will is, ſir, and, whatever violence it may do my own feelings, 〈◊〉 you my honor it ſhall be obeyed.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: I could?truſt you, Zelida—Nay, I will truſt you—but as for you—

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Oh lord, ſir, I'll give you my honour too, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: D. Zel.
sp.p: Sir, I pledge my word ſhe ſhall not ſtir out of my apartment.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Do you, Zelida? Well, I will not doubt hour word; you are a good girl, Zelida, a good girl! [To Jaquelina.] You, perhaps, would like to be magnetized once more—A raſcal! with his meſmerites and parachutes—Where the devil could the fellow pick up all that?—Ha! [The reſt of this ſpeech, aſide.] As ſure as fate—Don Salvador is at the bottom of this!—It is a ſcheme to make a fool of a philoſopher!—The old are to laugh and be laugh'd at!—It muſt be ſo—I'll ſend him a challenge. Employ his raſcally agents to make a fool of me!—I'll ſend him a challenge—Inſtantly!—A challenge!

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: Thus then are all my expectations blighted, and ſuch, and ſo tranſitory, are human joys!

lg.l: Hope points to happineſs, and, ſmiling,
Shews us where the Phantom lies;
But, the graſping hand beguiling,
From the touch it ſtarts and flies.
Thus, the butterfly the boy
With chacing wearied is, and croſs'd;
