Thus, when he'd ſeizeth' expected joy,
Tow'rds heaven it riſes and is loſt

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: So our philoſopher is in a pretty way! Don Pimiento won't leave him a whole bone.

sp.speaker: D. Zel.
sp.p: No; tho' My father is paſſionate, he is naturally merciful, and will rather frighten than hurt him.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: 'Pſhaw! madam, I am ſure he will half murder him. But you mean to let me go and tell Don Fernando what has happened.

sp.speaker: D. Zel.
sp.p: You ſhall not ſtir: I am determin'd to obey my father.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: And wilfully make yourſelf and Don Fernando miſerable.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: Not wilfully; I have no choice: if it depended upon me, his happineſs ſhould be the buſineſs and delight of my life.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: If? Why lord, madam, it does depend on you, and nobody but you. A pretty thing, indeed—

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: Silence, Jaquelina: I'll have no improper liberties taken with my father.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Why then, madam, your father ſhould not take improper liberties with you.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: I have only to do my duty, and hope for the beſt.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Hope, madam! Why, don't you know your father's temper? And didn't you hear him pledge his word and honour to Don Velaſco?

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: I did—Alas! there is no hope! Let conſcious rectitude, then, and reſignation be my ſupport.

sp.speaker: D. Zel
sp.l: When paſſion racks the virgin' heart,
Not ev'n allow'd to hope;
From duty fearful to depart,
What can ſhe do?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Elope.
I'd never ſit ſo pale and wan,
I'd never pine and mope;
I'd break from bondage, take the man,
And light as air elope.

sp.speaker: D. Zel.
sp.l: I'll patient ſit ſo pale and wan,
I'll patient pine and mope;
A duteous child ſure never can,
No—never will, elope.

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſabel, walking about in extreme anxiety, and ſpeaking only at intervals.
sp.p:
YES—yes, yes, I deſerve it—the puniſhment is juſt—I have loſt him for ever, and with him, for ever loſt my tranquillity. Will Laura never return?—By what ſtrange infaturation am I governed?—To be conſcious of one's folly!—of one's extreme abſurdity, even at the very moment when it is moſt predominant!—to feel it ſtrengthen in proportion as one feels its deſtructive tendency!—Can this be?—Yes, it is, it is!— (Rings.)
Enter a Footman. It not Laura come back yet?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: No, madam.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p:
Poſſeſſed by the tormenting ſpirit of ſilly female vanity—of capricious pride—My heart and my tongue in continual contradiction—my underſtanding and ſelf-love at eternal warfare—ever endeavoring to humble, and render the man I loved, abject; yet, certain to deſpiſe him, had he become ſo. Where can this girl be?—He'll perceive ſhe is ſent by my orders, and will deſpiſe me for my meanneſs. (rings.)
Enter a Footman. Do you hear any thing of Laura yet?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: No, madam.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Run, ſee if you can meet her, and tell her to make haſte.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Which way, madam?

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Towards Don—heavens! am I going to betray my weaknefs, even to my very footman?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Where, madam?

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: No where.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Don Fabricio's, madam?

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: So! my paſſions make me the ſport of my very ſervants!—What do you ſtand for?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Madam?

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Go, go, go.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Where, madam?

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: No where. (pettiſhly.) [Exit Footman, ſhrugging up his ſhoulders. Laughed at—deſpis'd—tortured.—

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Where have you been all this while?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Lord, madam! I have runn'd myſelf off my legs.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Have you ſeen Fabricio?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Oh yes, madam, I have ſeen him.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Tell me inſtantly what he ſays.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Says, madam?—I never heard a man talk ſo, and look ſo, in my life. He complains, and laughs, and ſighs, and ſwears, and prays, and weeps.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I never ſaw any poor gentleman in ſuch a taking. He calls you an angel, and a coquette, and his delight, and his torment, and his dear, and his devil; and vows he ſhall die if you are not his; and ſwears he'll never ſee you more.—He rav'd ſo, I declare he frighted me.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: So, he does not talk of coming?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: He ſaid, madam, he knew very well, you wanted him to come back.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Sure you did not tell him that I ſent you?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Oh, no, madam; you know how ſtrictly you charged me not.—And ſo he ſwore, he would rather die a thouſand times; and yet, madam, I do believe if he had but thought as how you had ſent me, he would have come directly; for he aſt me, over and over, whether you ſent me, or if you wanted to ſee him; and I vowed, and purteſted, I came of my own head.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Stupid wretch! why did you do that?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why, lord, madam, did not you bid me?—I did ſlip out a word or two, and then he was going to come all in a hurry, and then I was oblig'd to ſwear, and declare, that you knew nothing of the matter; and then he began (to utter ſuch dreadful oaths! I declare I was ſcarified.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Idiot!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why, lord, madam, I did not know what to do; I am ſure, I would have told him, with all my heart, what a condition you were in, if I dar'ſt.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Condition!—Oh, pride, pride!—How mean! how abject!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: And ſo, madam, he ſaid at laſt, he ſhould go and take a walk on the Prado; and ſo, madam, I do believe, that was as much as to ſay, that, if you wanted him, there you might find him.

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Wanted him!—This is inſupportable!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: And ſo, madam, if I might adviſe—

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why, madam, I am certain—

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: Hold your tongue I ſay—My preſent torments are not to be endured—yes, I deſerve every humiliation that can be inflicted on me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
Well, to be ſure, ſhe is in a ſtrange twitteration—I know ſhe is in fifty minds now—ſhe does not know whether ſhe ſhould go or ſtay, or be angry of ſorry, or humble, or obſtinate, or what—I can't ſay but I do hope he'll bring her proud ſtomach down. Such ſtrange fancies and fangles, and airs, and flights, and I will, and I won't—but lord, 'tis the way of all theſe fine ladies. Becauſe they have not one ſingle thing on earth to croſs them, they are always racking their brains to torment
themſelves—But ſome folks are fortunate, and ſome folks are misfortunate.

lg.l: Not all poor Laura's truth and love
Can her too faithleſs Sancho move!
Alas! poor Laura, forlorn, alone,
Thy Love has left thee here to moan!
Were thy poor boſom from love and from Sancho free,
Couldſt thou forget both his fondneſs and perfidy,
Or, did he know how to value thy conſtancy,
Oh! what a happy young maiden would Laura be!
Did he not ſmile on another, neglecting thee,
Did he not treat with diſdain thy integrity,
Did he remember the oaths he has ſworn to thee,
Oh! what a happy young maiden would Laura be!

div.stage: Enter Don Fabricio, walks about, melancholy and uneaſy, Pedro following.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Here he is—If I am not miſtaken, love, pride, and obſtinacy are each tormenting him by turns—Now to try whether I cannot incline the balance in favor of love— (approaches to Fabricio) Sir! young gentleman! may I crave your ear for a moment?

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Well, Sir!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Your name is Don Fabricio, Sir.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: And what then?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: You muſt underſtand Sir, there has been a evere combat, between my honour and my penchant.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Your—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: And as you, Sir, were the ſubject of contention, • is for that reaſon I intreat a hearing.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: I!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: You muſt have obſerved, Sir, there are certain pleaſing countenances that captivate the moment they are ſeen.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Your phiſiognomy, Sir, has that happy engaging caſt. I was ſtruck when I beheld it, and could not help inſtantly wiſhing myſelf an appendage to ſo placid, ſo mild, ſo ſweet a nobleman, for noble you certainly are.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: I would adviſe you, friend, to go on with your ſtory, or get out of my reach, leſt I ſhould convince you, I am not quite ſo mild, and ſo placid, as your thetorical flouriſhes pretend.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Ah no, Sir, I am in perfect ſecurity.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Are you? (Seems going to ſtrike him, and Pedro bows and looks in his face with a ſmile of bumble impudence. Fabricio can't forbear laughing) This is a ſtrange, odd, impudent fellow.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Were you not the amiable perſon I have been deſcribing, I could never reconcile my preſent proceeding to my conſcience.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Damn your conſcience, and your preſent proceeding! What's your buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I knew you had the manners of a nobleman! With what a grace you ſwear! ſo natural— (Obſerves Fabricio driven beyond his patience) I do not wonder at Donna Iſabel's paſſion for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Donna Iſabel! What do you know of Donna Iſabel?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: My name is Pedro, Sir.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Confound the fellow!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I am ſervant to Don Fernando, Sir.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: But Donna Iſabel—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Will ſoon be married to my maſter, Sir, if you don't prevent it.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Married!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: In revenge—Miſunderſtandings on all ſides! Donna Iſabel believes you falſe; my maſter ſuppoſes you in love with Donna Zelida; and they have agreed to be married, with a charitable hope you will hang yourſelf for vexation.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Impoſſible.

p.hi: Now as I knew this would make four true lovers miſerable, my penchant for you, Sir, has vanquiſhed the obſtacles my honour raiſed to the betraying of my maſter's ſecrets.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Can this be true?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Put me to my oath—Sir—

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Ungrateful, falſe, Iſabel!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, you miſtake the matter. 'Tis exceſs of love, and not inconſtancy. Offer her your hand, ſhe won't refuſe; lead her to church, and thus wipe off your old ſcore of troubles, and begin a new one.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: No—I am determined I'll go to the Prado—I will not eternally bend thus to a capricious temper.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: I am not maſter of myſelf.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Kind Sir—

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: I know not what to reſolve.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Permit me to inform you, gentle Sir, I feel another very ſtrong internal ſtruggle, at this very moment, between my poverty and my pride.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: What next?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Knowing your generoſity, my poverty would fain perſuade me to accept the purſe you are going to preſent me; but my pride, dreading to be thought ſelfiſh, is treating my poor poverty with that contempt with which pride always treats poverty.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Here, ſirrah, here is money for you; but obſerve, if I find you have been impoſing upon me—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I underſtand the conditions, Sir, and my ſhoulders ſhall be forth coming—They are oſtenſible.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Cruel, unjuſt Iſabel!

lg.l: The wayward tongue, fond Love repelling,
The frown-fraught brow, the ſcorn-taught eye,
Can theſe, which jealous fraud imply,
In ſuch an angel form find dwelling?
Yes! theſe extremes of contraſt dwell
In thee, too lovely Iſabel!

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Can taunts, and ſcoffs, and wild caprices,
Sully thoſe lips, by Venus giv'n,
The lover's fancied, hop'd-for heaven
Of ſweets, and ſmiles, and balmy kiſſes?
Yes! ſuch extremes of contraſt dwell
In thee, too lovely Iſabel!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: There he goes—the direct road to her houſe, determining all the way he won't go near her.—Really, Mr. Cupid, you are a droll little fellow.

lg.l: Cupid, ſure, of cunning knaves,
Is the chief, ſir.!
All his ſubjects are but ſlaves,
To their grief, ſir;
A ſlippery, frippery, fooliſh band;
For whim, and gold,
Bought and ſold;
By this mad, blind, boy trepann'd,:
In his pound,
When they're found,
Why then—fa, la, la, la,
Oh, the thief, ſir!

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Did you ſee him huff and ding,
When he's fallen!
Whimper, caper, curſe, and ſing,
Talk of killing!
Whiſtle, neſtle, come and go;
Fume, and fret,
His will to get;
Meaning yes, and anſwering no;
Till, at laſt,
The frolic paſt,
Why then—fa, la, la, la,
Oh, the villain!

lg.head: III.
lg.l: When a maid is young and coy,
And the lover
Symptoms of a baſhful boy
Should diſcover;
He'll loiter, titter, hide, and ſeek;
Nudge, and dodge,
And rap, and tap;
If purſu'd, will ſqueal, and ſqueak:
But if the boy
Prove too coy,
Why then—fa, la, la, la,
Oh, the rover!

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: When a youth is warm and bold,
Strong, unruly,
And the maiden fair, but cold,
Then why, truly,
Swearing, tearing, ſighing, dying,
Silly, ſad,
Sullen, mad,
Wearied with ſo much denying,
Death's the word!
Draws his ſword,
But then—fa, la, la, la,
Oh! the bully!

lg.head: V.
lg.l: All his antics pray relate,
They who can, ſir:
Young and old and ſmall and great
To trepan, ſir!
How he'll juggle, jeer, cajole,
Plague and pleaſe,
Entice and teize,
'Till they're under his controul,
How his ſpeech
Will men bewitch,
And then—Fa, la, la, la,
The Necromancer!

div.stage: SCENE changes to the houſe of Don Salvador.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Be under no apprehenſion, ſir; love will reconcile Don Fabricio, and Donma Iſabel: we may ſtill find ſome means of gaining Don Salvador's conſent; and as for Don Pimiento, I believe the greateſt Philoſopher living could not have paſſed upon him better.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: But is it not ſtrange I have not received any anſwer from Zelida! I begin to be upon the rack.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Jaquelina perhaps could not find any opportunity to ſlip out, fir.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Here, take this, return to Don Pimiento's, and convey, it as before; but do not come away, if poſſible, without bringing me an anſwer.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Never fear, ſir, you ſhall ſoon receive a good account of me—the old Don will rejoice to ſee me again.

div.stage: Enter Don Salvador, on the oppoſite ſide.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch an old fool! He's mad, there's no doubt but he is mad!

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: What's the matter, ſir?

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Matter, ſir! perhaps you can tell me what's the matter, ſir. Do you know any thing of any pretended Philoſopher?

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Sir! Philoſopher!

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: That old, unaccountable ape, Don Pimiento, ſends me word he'll toſs my Philoſopher in a blanket, and cut my throat.—He has ſent me a challenge, here! in direct terms!

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: A challenge, Sir!

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: But I'll cool him, I'll chaſtiſe his inſolence: he ſhall never ſtick pin thro' butterfly more.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Why, ſurely ſir, you won't think of fighting.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: What! receive a challenge, and from a tottering ſkin of parchment, full of inflammable air! but I'll drill him, I'll make it whiz out.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Loſt and undone! Where can this Fabio be?—Don Pimiento will murder Pedro, and I am more certain of loſing Zelida now than ever.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: He pretend to ſend a challenge!

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: But, ſir, tho' he has no more temper and underſtanding, I hope you will not ſo forget your character, ſtation and age.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Sir, I want none of your advice.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, my dear father, moderate your anger!

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Sir, I want none of your advice.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Conſider, ſir, that my happineſs depends upon the poſſeſſion of Zelida.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Then it has a very ſlender dependence indeed, for ſhe never ſhall be your's, ſhe never can be your's, I being ſully determined to cut her father's throat. Don't follow me; keep back.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Diſtraction! What is to be done? Fabio!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Run, inſtantly, and try to overtake Pedro. (recollecting himſelf) No, no; ſend ſomebody elſe after Pedro, and do you watch my father; he's gone with an intent to fight Don Pimiento. Think, invent ſome means of keeping them aſunder.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Me invent! lord, ſir, I am an animal of inſtinct, and—

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Don't ſtand prating, ſir, fly, follow my father; watch him, and if you can find no other means of preventing this ridiculous duel, raiſe the neighbourhood.— [Exit Fabio.]—Every thing conſpires to overwhelm me with vexation and deſpair. Pedro detected, the breach between our fathers widened, and Fabricio's irreconcilable quarrel with his miſtreſs.—Obſtacles and miſchieſs accumulate.—Oh, my Zelida! my angel! my life! either I am thine, or I am nothing!

lg.l: Oh love, thou powerful, pleaſing, pain!
The heart that owns thy mighty ſway
Shall ne'er recover peace again,
But waſte in ſighs the chearful day.
Can words deſcribe my countleſs fears;
While on the rack of doubt I lie;
While doom'd to paſs my time in tears,
Condemn'd without complaint to die?
In vain I wiſh for loſt repoſe;
In vain would abſence bring relieſ
Still love within my boſom, glows,
And death, alone, can calm my grief.

div.stage: SCENE changes to the Muſeum of Don Pimiento.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My maſter will be with you immediately, ſir; he deſired me to tell you, he is making preparations for a philoſophical experiment, but that—Oh, here he comes.—
sp.stage: Pedro and Don Pimiento, bowing; the latter ſtruggling to conceal his paſſion 'till he breaks out at opening the letter.]

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: This quick return, ſir, is exceedingly kind.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Oh, ſir!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: I aſſure you, ſir, I am ſuperlatively glad to ſee you; as it will give me infinite pleaſure to treat you as your high merit deſerves.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Pray, ſir—you confound me, ſir.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: May I take the liberty to aſk, moſt ſage ſir, whether you have prepared your ſecond letter to the very learned Doctor Don Lilibulero?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Oh, yes, ſir, I have it, here it is.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: And as curious, no doubt, as the firſt.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Oh! ſcientific! abſtruſe!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: And the philoſopher is by this time half made a fool of?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: That, ſir, nature made him.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Humph! [Turns aſide grinding his teeth.]—Well, ſir, ſhall I take this letter and give it to my maid? For, as ſhe delivered the laſt, ſhe will be the leſs liable to make any miſtake.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: True, ſir; that is a moſt philoſophic, and juſt remark.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: You ſend this without the ducats?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Yes, fir, yes; but I'll take care the young woman ſhall be fewarded hereafter.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: I will be ſtill more generous, ſir; for I will take care that you ſhall be rewarded at preſent.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Sir!—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Don't be impatient; ſtand where you are, young man; you ſhall be magnetiſed;—Here, raſcals! where are you all?

div.stage: Enter four ſervants, who lay hold of Pedro.
div.p: Now, Mr. Philoſopher, tho' you have viſited all regions, known, and unknown—, I'll try how you like the upper regions.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, ſir, have ſome mercy; do but liſten to me, and you ſhall hear.—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: As many lies as I pleaſe. You, I ſay, ſhall fly—fly—without a balloon.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Pray, gentlemen, do you have pity.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Conſider, I am a fellow ſervant.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Let' em conſider, if they dare.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Is there no forbearance?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: No mitigation?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Come, come; away with him.

sp.speaker: Zel.
sp.p: Fly! fly! my dear father—ſave yourſelf!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Why, how now! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Zel.
sp.p: Archers! Alguazils!—Mercy!—'Tis too late!—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: How, now, ſir; who are you?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Who, am I, ſir? My name is Joſepho Ribeiro; and my office is that of his Majeſty's Alguazil.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: And, pray, ſir, what buſineſs have you in my houſe?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I come, ſir, by order of the Supreme Council, to inform you, that you have loſt your cauſe with the Count de Cordova; and that you are condemn'd to pay five thouſand piſtoles; which, by order of the ſaid Count, and Court, I am now come to demand immediate payment of, without hindrance, let, or, delay; or, to take your perſon into cuſtody.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Confuſion! Damnation! Five thouſand piſtoles![At the entrance of the Alguazil, the ſervants, who hold Pedro, ſtand amazed; and Pedro, after obſerving what paſſes, with ſurprize, eſcapes.] It is impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Sir, if you won't take my word, here's my authority.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Ruin, and diſtraction!

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: My orders, ſir, are preciſe, and ſtrict. You know the power of the Count.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: I have here, indeed, too fatal a proof of it.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Therefore, ſir, either, deliver me the five thouſand piſtoles, or, deliver your body into the keeping of theſe four worthy gentlemen.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Five thouſand piſtoles is a ſum not to be paid thus inſtantaneouſly.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I have told you what are my orders, ſir.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Surely, ſir, you can delay a few minutes.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p:
Why, ſir, as you ſeem a gentleman of underſtanding, I will do every thing in my
power to oblige you. However ſir, I can aſſure you, my orders are very ſevere.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: Ah! Sir, ſtay but till my father's friends can be informed of his misſortune, and, I will for e •• r bleſs and pray for you.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Don't terrify yourſelf, my child—Tho' my enemy be powerful and proud, he ſhall find I am not totally deſerted.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: I hope not, yet doubt is dreadful.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: But it makes certainty more ſweet.

sp.speaker: Zel.
sp.p: It does! it does!
sp.stage: [Exeunt Don Pimiento, Alguazil and Archers; manet Zelida.]

div.head: SONG.
div.l: When o'er the wold, the heedleſs lamb
Hath, 'till the duſky twilight, ſtray'd;
His ſimple plaints cry "here I am!
"Of night and ſolitude afraid."
But if, far off, his dam he hears,
Ecchoing, oft, the mournful bleat,
He runs, and ſtops, and hopes, and ſears,
And bounds with pleaſure! when they meet.

div.stage: SCENE changes to the outſide of Don Pimiento's Houſe.
Enter Pedro from the houſe, frighten'd.
div.p: Oof!—I have eſcaped by miracle!—Oh that damn'd blanket!—Our affairs too, worſe than ever!—And the devil to pay within!—Where is my unfortunate maſter?—I muſt endeavour to find him, and inform him of all his miſeries.
div.stage: Enter Don Salvador looking at his watch.
div.p: I am a quarter before my time—I warrant I teach you to invite me to put on my ſword and take private walks with you, my teſty philoſopher.
div.stage: Walks up to the back of the ſtage.]

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I can ſee by his countenance our old Don is determin'd to fight—I wiſh I could find, ſome means to—Ha! I've a thought! If I can but ſucceed, it will be a maſter-ſtroke!—I'll venture.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.stage: [Coming down the ſtage looking at his watch.]
sp.p: He is willing not to come before his time; but he is right to defer his execution as long as poſſible.

div.stage: Re-enter Fabio, ſobbing and pretending to weep, not groteſquely, but as naturally as poſſible.
div.p: How now, ſir, what is the matter with you, ſir?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Oh my poor maſter! Poor Don Fernando!

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: What, what of him?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Dead, ſir.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Dead!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Dying—Mortally wounded, ſir— [Sobbing.] The ſur-ur-urgeon ſays, ſir, the ſword of Don Fabri-icio has paſſed in a ri-ight line thro' the left lobe of his lungs, and that it's im-im-im-impoſſible he can live for a quarter of an hour.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Where—where is he?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: He li-ies with his handkerchief ſtuff'd in his ſide, and his ha-a-and over his mouth, holding in his breath, that it may-ayn't depart till you have given him your bleſſing.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Ah! where is he? where is he?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: This way, ſir, under the walls of the Buen Retiro Palace. [Going, turns round and ſtops.] My heart bleeds to think of the tor-or-ortures he this mo-o-oment endures.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: My poor-oor-oor Fernando!

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Bleſs me, ſir! What's the matter!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Avaunt, Satan—Take care, ſir,—his ghoſt is come to haunt you.
sp.stage: [Don Salvador perceives the trick that has been play'd him, and his countenance changes from ſorrow to anger. Fabio winks, and endeavours to make Fernando underſtand him.]

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: I'll haunt you, raſcal!

div.stage: Re-enter Pedro—[Takes Fernando aſide, and whiſpers.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Alguazils and Archers!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Fact, I aſſure you, ſir; they are now in the houſe.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Madneſs and diſtraction! Were there not impediments enough before to my happineſs! Follow me.

div.stage: [Exeunt Fernando and Pedro into the houſe.]

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: I'll teach you to play your tricks upon me— [Sees Fernando entering Pimiento's houſe, and calls.] Harkye, ſir! Fernando!—Fernando, I ſay!—Where the devil are you going, ſirrah?—He won't hear—A headlong!—I'll fetch him out! I'll—

div.stage: SCENE changes to the inſide of the Houſe.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: If you will hear what I have to ſay, I am certain you will not think of purſuing this quarrel further; at leaſt not at this moment.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Sir, I tell you I am come with a reſolution to cut his throat; and the ſayings of neither you, nor Seneca, nor all the wiſe men that ever exiſted, could make the leaſt impreſſion on me.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: What, ſir, would you inſult an enemy in diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: In diſtreſs!

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Don Pimiento is now, ſir, in the hands of Archers, arreſted at the ſuit of the Count de Cordova, for five thouſand piſtoles.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: How, how? Which way could Don Pimiento owe the Count de Cordova five thouſand piſtoles?

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: By decree of the Supreme Council, he has loſt his cauſe. Juſtice was on the ſide of Don Pimiento, but power on the ſide of his adverſary; and, unfortunately for Spain, power is here ſuperior to Juſtice.

div.stage: Enter Zelida, in tears, followed by Don Pimiento, Alguazil and Archers.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: For mercy's ſake, ſir, do not hurry my father away thus. Wait till he can ſend for his friends.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: We have ſhewn you our orders, madam.

sp.speaker: D. Sal. (whiſpers Fernando, and gives him a key)
sp.p: Do you hear, ſir? fly.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Dry your tears, Zelida, you are a good child.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: You ſeem in haſte, Mr. Alguazil: Where are you going to take this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: To priſon, ſir.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Don Salvador! What, ſir, are you come to infult me at ſuch a time as this?

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Inſult you, ſir? Pray, ſir, when did you know me inſult any gentleman in diſtreſs?—And pray, Mr. Alguazil, what is your reaſon for taking Don Pimiento to priſon?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I am ſo commanded, ſir, becauſe he can't pay his debts.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Can't he?—but if he can't, I can, and I command you to let him remain in his own houſe.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Don Salvador—What do you mean?

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: What do I mean!—Are not you a gentleman, and a Spaniard, Don Pimiento?

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Yes, I have that honor, ſir.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p:
Then how dare you aſk me, what I mean, when I ſee a perſon of that deſcription oppreſs'd, and
have the power to ſuccour him?—What do you think I can mean?—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.stage: (Greatly moved, and taking Don Salvador by the hand.)
sp.p: Don Salvador, you—you are a gentleman—a true Caſtilian—and I revere you—and I am ſorry I quarrell'd with you—but I can't accept your favor.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: No! Why then you are a proud—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: No, it is not pride; but my honor is pledg's to Don Velaſco, and the union of our children is impoſſible.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: I perceive, Don Pimiento, you are determined I ſhall cut your throat. Do you think I come like a Uſurer, with my money in one hand, and my clauſes and conditions in the other, Cent. per Cent. in my own favor?

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: Oh, ſir! I ſhall love and revere you as long as I live.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Don Salvador, I am ſorry?I quarrell'd with you.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: You are the nobleſt, the beſt of men.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Well, but gentlement—

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Oh! what your hurry is not over yet?

sp.speaker: Don Fer.
sp.p: Sir, the money is below.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Pleaſe to walk down, ſir, with this young gentleman, and he will ſee you ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Now, Don Pimiento, if you think I have injured you, I am ready to give you ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Don Salvador, I feel the generous and noble manner of your proceeding. You have reſcued me from the power of a malignant and, mean enemy, and, without drawing your ſword, have vanquiſh'd me.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p:
I believe, Don Pimiento, we have both been to blame. However, for my own part, I'll give you my promiſe never to diſpute about things I don't underſtand any more, nor ever more laugh at philoſophy, eſpecially in your preſence.—He that does a gentleman a pecuniary favor, and afterwards takes improper liberties with him,
ſhews he meanly expended his money to purchaſe a ſlave, and not generouſly to acquire a friend.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Joy, joy, my Zelida!—Permit me, Don Pimiento, to introduce my friends.

div.stage: (Don Pimiento bows aſſent, and Fernando introduces Don Fabricio, and Iſabel. They ſalute the company.)

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Give me leave, Donna Zelida, to preſent this lady to you, who is now the better part of myſelf.—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Married!

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: Yes, ſir. I hope you will excuſe—

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Excuſe—ſir, I'll—I'll—Zelida!

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: This is moſt fortunate!

sp.speaker: Donna Iſa.
sp.p: I will own to you, Donna Zelida, that, half an hour ago, I conſidered you as the moſt dangerous perſon in the world, perhaps as my enemy; I ſhall now be proud of your friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Donna Zel.
sp.p: Dear madam, you give me life and happineis!

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: Here, Don Fernando, tho' there is not a better girl in all Spain, no, nor in all the univerſe, than my Zelida, I am certain you will deſerve her.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.stage: (Receives her hand and kiſſes it with rapture.)
sp.p: I will at leaſt endeavour to do ſo, ſir.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: But, pray, give me leave to aſk, young gentleman, is not that the Philoſopher?

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: I am ſorry, and aſhamed.—But, indeed, ſir, it was a trick of the ſellow's own invention.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Oh, yes, ſir! don't rob me of the honor of the invention.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Silence, ſir!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Ah! thus are men of genius treated by the Great, when they no longer ſtand in need of their aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: And Don Salvador—

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: Knew nothing of the matter.

sp.speaker: D. Pimi.
sp.p: I aſk your pardon.

sp.speaker: D. Sal.
sp.p: And the inquiſitor! Ah, raſcal! It's well I happen to be in a very good humor.—But keep out of my way, the firſt time thou ſee'ſt me angry.

sp.speaker: D. Fab.
sp.p: The rogue play'd me a trick among the reſt; but he did me a favor; and has ſo ready a wit that he deſerves to be rewarded, as well as pardoned.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Gentlemen are ſo apt to forget their promiſes—otherwiſe Don Fernando is under a promiſe to make my fortune.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: That muſt depend upon your behavior.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Depend, depend.—I obſerve your people in power are always exceedingly anxious to keep a man of talents in a ſtate of dependance. They feel they have robb'd him of his birthright, and even grudge him his poor meſs of potage.

sp.speaker: D. Fer.
sp.p: Well, ſir; you ſhall find a gentleman, for once, who will keep his promiſe.—You have merit, and I ſhould ill deſerve the happineſs I now enjoy, were I to let merit languiſh, neglected, and without its reward.

sp.speaker: PEDRO.
sp.l: To troubles, then, a truce;
With the berry berry's juice
We'll be merry merry, while we may:
For, it's very very true,
He looks very very blue,
Who died only yeſterday!

sp.speaker: ZELIDA and ISABEL.
sp.l: Now faith and affection, united, agree;
Their efforts have worthily won us;

sp.speaker: FERNANDO and ZELIDA.
sp.l: And the Loves and the Graces, in concert, decree,
To ſhower down happineſs on us.

sp.speaker: Chorus,
sp.p: To troubles, &c.

sp.speaker: Don SALVADOR.
sp.l: In mirth let us vie! let the wine ſparkle high!
O'er Old Time let us King it and Queen it!

sp.speaker: Don PIMIENTO.
sp.l: For while the heart glow,
And with joy overflows,
We live millions of years in a minute!

sp.speaker: CHORUS.
sp.p: To troubles then a truce, &c.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: THE Paſſages between inverted Commas, are neceſſarily omitted in Repreſentation. The third Song in the third Act • s written by a Friend of the Author's, and • wo others have before appeared in Print.
